subject: RE: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Oh it will become one, trust me :-) Tests (not just unit tests, all tests) should go as fast as possible.  The faster they go, the more inclined developers
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> For what it's worth I do almost exactly this. However I do
> reparse on every test method, and it's not that big a deal.

Oh it will become one, trust me :-)

Tests (not just unit tests, all tests) should go as fast as possible. The
faster they go, the more inclined developers will be to run them on a
regular basis or, ideally, every time before they commit something.

When your tests start taking a long time, they only get run at night and the
"failure report/fix/retest" cycle takes increasingly longer, making it
harder to identify new breakages.

When I try to optimize the speed of my tests, the first thing I do is appy
the principle "Don't Repeat Yourself". Not in terms of code, but of
runtime. If something only needs to be run once, I make sure it only gets
run once. Having as much control as possible on this was of paramount
importance to me, which is why TestNG extends JUnit's setUp/tearDown
principle to work around test classes, test suites and even test groups.
This gives you maximal control on the granularity of your setUp/tearDown
cycle.

So my question to you is: why do you reparse this file on every test method
when it's not necessary? Because JUnit doesn't give you any
"setUp/tearDown" method around classes?

> The key is that I do the reparse for large files in each test
> method rather than in setUp or the constructor so that those
> methods that don't need to parse the file don't do it.

In this case, I would recommend breaking down your test class in a parent
class for all the test methods that don't need this file and a subclass for
all the test methods that do need this file. Then you can put the reparse
of your file in setUp(), which -- as someone said earlier -- makes the
intent obvious.

Let me stress this point further.

In JUnit, you have four ways to initialize / tear down your test, and they
are *all* equivalent:

- At the beginning and end of each test method
- In setUp()/tearDown()
- In the constructor
- At the field declaration level

I find that confusing as hell, so I *strongly* recommend to use
setUp/tearDown at the exclusion of everything else. Again, the idea is to
make the intent obvious.
